She will share this loan with her loan group BEIJING which totals two people who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to repair her cooking place and cover an open area with iron sheets to protect her clients from rain and sun.

loans.name: Mti Mrefu Group

texts.en:
Sharifa is in her early thirties, and is married with three school-aged children and one younger child. For eight years now, Sharifa has been providing an income for her family by running a grocery business. She opens her business from 2pm to 10pm every working day, and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This will be Sharifa's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to restock drinks such as beers, sodas, water and spirits. Sharifa has paid back her previous loan successfully.  She used the profit generated to cover household expenses and school fees for her children. Sharifa will use this loan to buy take-away soft drinks including sodas and water, and crates of beers. Sharifa dreams that one day she will be able to build her family a house.

Sharifa will share this loan with her loan group ”MTI MREFU" which has four members in total. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy take away soft drinks including sodas and water, and crates of beers.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy new business clothes and raw ingredients like rice, cooking oil, maize flour, baking flour and others; also a TV and digital deck for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to order new stocks of eggs for her business.

loans.name: Karoti Group

texts.en:
Maria is a single woman and a mother of one son who is in school. She is aged early thirties and has three years' experience in business. Maria currently makes her living by running a business selling beauty products: women's clothes, cosmetics and other women's products.  Because of her small capital, Maria runs her business by walking door-to-door which makes her very tired when she gets back home from her business. She starts her business at 8 am and works till 6 pm each working day and is able to make a good monthly return. 

This will be Maria's second loan request from Kiva partner Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to meet the demand of her pending customers by ordering more new products. Maria has paid back the whole loan successfully. She used the received profit to buy a plot of land and covered household food expenses and school fees.  She will use this loan to buy new business products: clothes and cosmetics. She dreams of being a successfully businesswoman.

She will share this loan with her loan group ”Karoti” which consists of three members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy new business goods: clothes and cosmetics.

loans.name: Lotus Group

texts.en:
Yusuph, who was born in the early 1960s, is married and has got two daughters and two sons. All of his children are in school. Yusuph, who is a chairperson of the Lotus group, has been earning his living by running a clothes business. When he gets back home from his clothing business, Yusuph extends his workday by selling charcoal as a business.  He starts his business day from 8 am and works to 6 pm per working day and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This is Yusuph’s twelfth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used the previous loans to buy new products so as to make his business grow.  Yusuph used his business profit to pay for his children's school fees and household expenses. With this new loan request, he will buy fabrics and sacks of charcoal. He dreams of improving his business and supporting his children up to university level.  

He will share this loan with his loan group "Lotus” which consists of 13 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy fabrics and sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Kimanga Group

texts.en:
Emeriki, who is in his mid-twenties, is single. For two years now, he has made his living by running a motorbike business, commonly known as bodaboda in Tanzania. He starts his service from 8:00 am and goes to 7:00 pm. Emeriki sometime wakes up very early in the morning or finishes at midnight if there are still customers requiring services and/or his expectation went bad. By working these long hours, he is able to make a good monthly profit. 

Emeriki is requesting for a new loan from Tujijenge Tanzania which he will use to pay for his motorbike maintenance and buy a few spare parts for his bike. In the coming days, he would like to become a good businessman, owning more motorbikes.

 He will share this loan with his loan group "KIMANGA” which has four persons. The people in the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to pay for maintenance of his motorbike and buy a few spare parts for his bike.

loans.name: Love Group

texts.en:
Martha, who is aged early 30s, is currently running a business selling soft drinks, beers, spirits and wine (an off-licence business). With her husband's support, Martha has managed  to grow her business. She has been in this business for a period of three years now. Martha and her husband together have got a boy and a girl who are in school.  Her business is open from 3 pm to midnight each working day and she is able to make a very good monthly profit. 

This will be her second loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to pay her business rent and helpers, painted her business place, and replaced her old grocery chairs with new ones. She has paid back in full the entire previous loan. Martha’s business profit was used to plough back into her business, and also covered part of her home expenses. She saved a small amount for unforeseen events. She will use the requested loan to restock new drinks and replace a broken table and chairs. She thanks Tujijenge for helping her business to improve.  In the coming years, Martha dreams of changing her business to be like a Casino. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "LOVE” which consists of four members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to restock new drinks and replace broken table and chairs.

loans.name: Kulangwa Group

texts.en:
Said, who is in his early 40s, is married and is a father of two sons and two daughters who are in school. He currently makes his living by running two small businesses. One is a retail shop, where he sells airtime, dry food items, and other items. He is also managing a genge, selling fruits and vegetables. Said has been in his enterprise for 20 years, just after finishing the primary level of school. He works at his business from 6am to 8pm each working day and he is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be his sixth loan request with Tujijenge Tanzania. With the previous loans, all of which he had successfully paid back, Said restocked his new retail shop inventories and he bought two new weighing machines for his shop. He used his business profit to build a house, where he is living now, and he bought a TV and a digital deck. 

Said will use this loan to buy liters of kerosene, which seems to be more in demand in his place, and he will restock his retail shop and genge business. He dreams to one day be able to own a wholesale business. 

Said will share this loan with his loan group, Kulangwa Group, which consist of five members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy liters of kerosene, which seems to be more in demand in his place, and to restock his retail shop and genge business.

loans.name: Tunaweza Mbagala Group

texts.en:
Ramadhani, who is in his early 40s, is married and has three children who are all still going to school. He has been running a general store business for three years now. He works from 6 am to 10 pm daily and is able to make a very good monthly profit.

This will be Ramadhani's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He wants to use the loan to buy out of stock items for his store. He dreams of making his shop on the international level.  

Ramadhani will share this loan with his loan group "TUNAWEZA MBAGALA" which has five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy the out of stock items for his store.

loans.name: Puma Group

texts.en:
Glory, who is in her early 40s, is married and has three children who are in school. For six years now, Glory has been managing a couple of small businesses. She is running a poultry business where she buy chicks and grows them. After six weeks, she sells them. She is also managing a fabrics and liquid soap business door to door. Glory works from 5 a.m. to 5 p.m. per working day and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This is her eleventh loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy fabrics, a mixture for making liquid soaps, and foods for her poultry. Glory paid back all of her previous loans successfully. She used the business profit to buy a plot of farm land and to pay for school fees and home expenses. Glory will use this loan to restock all of her businesses. She dreams of having a business of broiler foods.
 
She will share this loan with her loan group, ”Puma,” which consists of two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to restock all of her businesses.

loans.name: Serengeti Group

texts.en:
Easther, who is in her early 30s, is married and has one school child. 

For five years now, she has been managing her life by running a beauty salon. Easther believes that Tujijenge, Kiva's partner, will be of great help to her as she will be able to offer better products and improve her customer service. She runs her business from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

From Tujijenge Tanzania, this is her fifth loan request. She will use the loan to buy salon working equipment. Her previous loans, all of which she paid back successfully, were used to buy business requirements like cosmetics, dyes, etc. Easther used her business profit to cover school fees and household expenses. She hopes to open a big salon. 

Easther will share this loan with her loan group,”Serengeti,” which consists of two members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy salon equipment.

loans.name: Mpunga Group

texts.en:
Mohamedi, who is in his early 40s, is married and has two sons and a daughter. Two of them are in school while one has finished ordinary level. 

For six years now, Mohamedi has owned a shop where he runs tailoring activities. He also sells clothes in the same shop. Mohamedi works from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. per working day and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This will be his sixth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. With his previous loans, all of which he paid back successfully, he bought clothes and tailoring materials for his shop. With his profit, he built two rooms for his family and covered school fees and household expenses. 

Mohamedi will use this loan to buy clothes and working materials for his tailoring. He dreams of opening another shop.

He will share this loan with his loan group, “Mpunga,” which consists of seven members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy clothes and working materials for his tailoring.

loans.name: Sangara Group

texts.en:
Pili, who is in her early thirties, is married and a mother of two children, a boy and girl. The children live at home and are in school. She is the head of this loan group, Sangara, which has two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

For ten years now, Pili has made a living for her family by selling fish. She sells them locally but will buy fish from the market and travel upcountry to sell them. When she isn’t out of town, she works from 7:00 a.m. to noon. She is able to make a good monthly profit.

Pili used a previous loan through Tujijenge Tanzania to buy fish to sell. She paid that entire loan back successfully. She is now applying for a 6,000,000 TZS loan to be split between the group’s two members. She will use her portion of the loan to buy more fish to sell upcountry.

Pili has used her profits to reinvest in her business and to cover part of school and home expenses. She would love to be able to own a big clothes shop one day.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell upcountry.

loans.name: Good Work Group

texts.en:
Amina is in her early 40s and is single with a boy who lives at home. Amina’s boy is in school. She is living at the city where is easier to run her business. For two years now, Amina has made her family living by running a food stall business. Her business is small and she runs it at a hardworking place where she pays rent. She runs her business from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily and is able to make a small monthly profit. 

Amina is requesting a first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy cooking supplies like a sack of rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, maize and baking flour. In the coming days, Amina would like to build her own business place and make her family life better. 

She will share this loan with her loan group, ”Good Work,” which consists of three members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy cooking supplies like rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, maize and baking flour.

loans.name: Makoka Group

texts.en:
Mustafa is a member of the Makoka group who dedicates his time to his own business. Jointly with his group, Mustafa is able to request and receive a loan and make improvements to his life. 

He is currently aged in his late 30s. Mustafa is married and taking care of his four children who are enrolled to school. For six years now, he has been running a genge duka retail shop, where he sells cooking oil, soaps, matchboxes, airtime, rice, beans and fruits and vegetables. He opens his shop from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. per working day and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This is his second loan request from Kiva partner Tujijenge Tanzania. He will use it to replenish out-of-stock stock products in his genge duka. Mustafa used his previous loan to restock his business for daily demand and has paid back the loan successfully. He used the business profit to cover his household and school expenses. In the coming days, Mustafa dreams of expanding his business more to earn a high return. 

He will share this loan with his loan group, Makoka, which has two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to replenish out-of-stock products in his genge duka retail shop

loans.name: Tupendane Kongowe Group

texts.en:
Khadija, who is in her early 30s is married and has three children, two of whom go to school. The last child is still small. She has been selling mattresses from different companies since 1997. She works from 8 am to 6 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be  Khadija's 17th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to buy mattresses of different types and sizes. She has paid back all her loans successfully. She used the profit to buy a plot of land, pay school fees, and buy a sofa set, a TV set, and beds. She also covered household expenses. She is doing fine with the loan. She will use this loan to buy more mattresses to resell. She dreams of having a very big mattresses company.

Khadija will share this loan with her loan group "Tupendane Kongowe" which has three members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more mattresses to resell.

loans.name: Jitegemee Group

texts.en:
Dorothea, who is in her early fifties, is divorced. She has four children, only one of whom is still in school. For the past five years she has sold vegetables and bites, or snacks, that she makes herself. She works from 11:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. daily and makes a fair monthly profit.

Dorothea leads this group, Jitegemee, that has four members total. She has received and successfully paid back 21 prior loans from Tujijenge Tanzania. She is now applying for a 4,700,000 TZS loan on behalf of her group; the members will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

Dorothea used previous loans to buy sacks of flour, cooking oil, charcoal and vegetables. She used previous profits to pay for school fees and household expenses. She will use her portion of this loan to buy sugar, flour, cooking oil and coconut milk to make more bites so she can meet customer demand. She will also use her profits to pay school fees and household expenses.

Dorothea dreams of one day building her own house.

loans.use: to buy sugar, baking flour, cooking oil and coconut  milk for making better bites and meet her  customer's demand.

loans.name: Jipe Moyo Yombo Group

texts.en:
Halima, who is in her mid 40s, is married with five children, and only one is still at school. She has been a food vendor and has run a video shop for three years now. She works from 8 p.m. to after midnight daily, and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Halima's fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to open a video shop, which she does in the morning, and bought more stock of food, which made her sell to more people. She works hard and it shows. She has paid back all her loans successfully. She used the profit to pay school fees, bought a shamba and paid household expenses. She dreams of owning a hotel.  

Halima will share this loan with her loan group, "Jipe Moyo Yombo," which has a total of seven members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to restock the missing food items

loans.name: Best Group

texts.en:
Mary, who is in her early 40’s, is married with four children who are still in school.  She has been running a retail shop for two years now.  She works from 6 A.M. to 10 P.M. daily, and is able to make a very good monthly profit.  This will be Mary's second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to start her retail shop.  She used the have a food cafe.  She is doing great, and has paid back her loan successfully.  She used the profits to pay school fees and household expenses.  She will use this loan to buy the missing items in her shop inventory.  She dreams of opening a wholesale shop.

Mary will share this loan with her loan group "BEST" with two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy the missing items in her shop inventory.

loans.name: Mtazamo Group

texts.en:
Juma, who is in his early 30's, is married and has four children (two sons and two daughters) who are in school.  Juma wakes up early in the morning (7 am) to board a bus to go to his business market; he gets back home at 7 pm. This is Juma's daily schedule; he is able to make a very small monthly profit. 

Juma and his group members have formed a group to improve their lives. By doing this, Juma is able to receive loans which improve his life. His business was small at the beginning, and prior to loan from Tujijenge. Now he is looking to upgrading after receiving three loans. 

Juma used these loans to restock business radios. He used the received business profit to put back to his business, and covered his family food and school expenses.  Juma paid back the loans successfully. 

With the requested loan, Juma will buy new and modern radios, which are in demand by his customers.

In the coming years, Juma would like to be a businessman with a big radio shop. 

He will share this loan with his loan group,” MTAZAMO GROUP”, which consists of two members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy new and modern radios which are in demand by his customers.

loans.name: Happy Group

texts.en:
Sheila, who is in her late 30s, is single with two children who are still in school. She has been running two businesses, a cafe where she sells food and also a grocery. She has been in these businesses for one year now.  She works from 5am to midnight daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. 

This will be Sheila's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania which she wants to use for buying a good stock of food, beer, sodas and water. She is really happy with the loan. She dreams of building her own house.

Sheila will share this loan with her loan group, "Happy Group", which has a total of five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy a good stock of food, beer, sodas and water.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to restock her grocery with new drinks demanded mostly by her customers.

loans.name: Mambo Mapya Group

texts.en:
Miriam, who is in her late 30s, is married. She has been managing her family by running several businesses. Since 2011, she has been running a beauty salon where she also sells hair and beauty products. Miriam is also running a shop selling soft drinks. Lastly, she is engaged with decoration activity, but is not so active, since she is able to receive sometimes one order per month. She works from 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. daily, and is able to make a good monthly profit.

Miriam is requesting a loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. This will be her first loan request, which she will use to buy hair products and soft drinks for her business.

Miriam is a woman of business habit, dreaming to be a successful woman having a big business. She will share this loan with her loan group “Mambo Mapya", which totals five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy hair products and soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Alpha Na Omega Group

texts.en:
Irene is in her early 50s and is a mother of two children, one of which is studying.  She has been taking care of her family and children since her husband passed away. She is a mother known for being responsible, hardworking, and having the desire to succeed for her family. For a period of eight years, Irene has made her living by managing two ventures. One is poultry and the other is a charcoal business. Irene wakes up early in the morning (5:00am) for her poultry business especially when she has small chicks, because they need to be checked on carefully.  Her business activities end up at 08:00pm but sometimes she wakes up frequently at night to look after her chicks, especially to make sure they have enough food, water, or that the light is on and other requirements. Irene is currently managing 500 chicks, but she dreams of reach up to 1,000 chicks per month. From her business, Irene is able to make a very good monthly profit. 

This is her first loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use this loan to buy chicks in order to reach 600 chicks, which is 100 more from her current size. Irene appreciates the loan service from Kiva via Tujijenge Tanzania since it enables people through financial support to change their lives. In the coming days, she would like to finish building her house (things left over by her husband at the roof level). 

She will share this loan with her loan group” ALPHA NA OMEGA” which consists of six members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy chicks for her poultry business

loans.name: Mistubishi Group

texts.en:
Animalye, who is in her late 20s is single.  She has been running a business of selling charcoal for six months now.  She works from 07am to 06pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.  

This will be Animalye's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania which she will use for buying sacks of charcoal to meet her customers' demands. She dreams of selling charcoal at wholesale prices.

Animalye will share this loan with her loan group "MISTUBISHI" which has three members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy sacks of  charcoal to meet her customers' demands

loans.name: Ujamaa Group

texts.en:
Angela, who is in her mid 40s, is a widow with four children.  Three of her children are in school and one is married.  She has sold charcoal and clothes door to door for five years.  She works from 5:30am to 9:00pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Angela's 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to start a door-to-door clothing business and bought sacks of charcoal for her charcoal business.  She has successfully repaid her loans. She used the profit to pay school fees, build two rooms, buy bricks and cement and cover household expenses.  She will use this loan to buy sacks of charcoal to meet her customers' demand.  She dreams of owning a successfully charcoal business.

Angela will share this loan with her loan group "Ujamaa" with four members who will hold each other accountable to repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal to meet her customers' demand.

loans.name: Ulezi Group

texts.en:
Daud is in her late 20s, married, and has  two school-aged boys. He has run a fruits and vegetable business since 2000.  He works from 4:00am to 10:00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Daud's 5th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  He used the previous loans to prepare the land, plant more fruits and vegetables seeds, and  sell his fruits and vegetables. 

He has sucessfully repaid his loans.  He used the profits to pay school fees and cover household expenses. He will use this loan to  buy seed and plant fruits and vegetables on a large farm.  He plans to sell more fruits and vegetables this season.  He dreams of owning a liquid soap business.

Daud will share this loan with his loan group "Ulezi" which has eight members who hold each other accountable to repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy more seed and plant his fruits and vegetables on a large farm.

loans.name: Mapatano Group

texts.en:
Enilika, who is in her early 40s, is married with five children who are still in school. She has been selling furniture for seven years now.  She works from 8 am to 6 pm daily and is able to make a very good monthly profit.

This will be Enilika's fifth loan form Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to buy good types of wood and managed to make fast class furniture.  She has paid back all her loans successfully. She used the profit to pay school fees, to start building her house and to pay household expenses.  She will use this loan to buy more wood for making more furniture.  She dreams of opening a workshop for displaying her furniture.

Enilika will share this loan with her loan group "Mapatano", which has five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more wood to make furniture.

loans.name: Khanga Group

texts.en:
Tabu, who is in her mid 30s, is single, with four children, two boys and two girls and all of them are still in school. She has been running a retail shop business for ten years now.  She works from 6am to 11pm daily and she is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Tabu's 11th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy the fast-moving items in her shop stock and she has successfully paid back all her loans.  She is happy with the loan and she appreciates whomever has supported their group. Tabu used the profit to pay school fees and household expenses. 

She will use this loan to increase stock in the shop's inventory. She dreams of becoming an international businesswoman.

Tabu will share this loan with her loan group, Khanga Group, with four members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to increase stock in the shop's inventory.

loans.name: Dove Group

texts.en:
Hellen, who is in her late 30s, is married and has three children, one of whom goes to school and the other two are still young.  She has been selling fruits, vegetables, and soft drinks. She has been in her businesses for two years now.

This will be Hellen's 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania which she will use to restock on fruits,vegetables, sodas, juice and water.  She dreams of expanding her business.

Hellen will share this loan with her loan group "Dove" which has two members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy fruits, vegetable, sodas, juice and water to resell

loans.name: Faidika Group

texts.en:
Daines is in her mid-40s, single and has two children who are still going to school. She has been running two businesses: a beauty salon and charcoal sales. She has been in business for three years now. She works from 7 a.m. to 9 p.m. daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be Daines's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She wants to use the loan to buy salon equipment and sacks of charcoal to meet her customers' demand. She dreams of building her own house.

Daines will share this loan with her loan group, Faidika, which has five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy salon equipment and sacks of charcoal to meet her customers' demand.

loans.name: Mtamakulanga Group

texts.en:
Paulo, who is in his late 20s, is married with two children, one of them in school and the other too young for school.  He has been selling livestock since 2008. He works from 6 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. 

This will be Paulo's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania which he wants to use for buying cattle, goats, chicks and chicken feed.  He dreams of owning a retail shop.

Paulo will share this loan with his loan group, Mtamakulanga, which has 10 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy cattle, goats, chicks and chicken feed.

loans.name: Tunu Group

texts.en:
Nasma, who is in her mid 30s, is single with one daughter who is still at school. She has been selling clothes, fabrics and sarongs door-to-door for three years now. She works from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Nasma's first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania which she wants to use for buying clothes, sarongs and fabrics to sell to more clients.  She dreams of building her own house. Nasma will share this loan with her loan group, Tunu, which has 10 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy clothes, sarongs and fabrics to sell to more clients.

loans.name: Busara 1A Group

texts.en:
Hawa, who is in her early 20s, is married and has one child, who is in school. For two years now, Hawa had made her living by running a food stall business offering breakfast and lunch. This business requires tolerance due to its working environment and the nature of customers. Hawa is known for being a good service provider and working hard. She always wakes up at 5.00 a.m. to work at her food stall business and ends her day at 6:00 p.m. She is able to make a good profit. 

Hawa joined with her group, Busara, to access loan supports from Tujijenge which opens a door toward fulfilling her dreams. Her group totals four members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. She is now requesting a second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy utensils, rice, sugar, liters of cooking oil and other business needs. With her first loan, she bought business stock and working equipment. She used her business profit to buy a motorbike, pay school fees and some household expenses. In the coming years, Hawa dreams to own a hotel.

loans.use: to buy utensils, rice, sugar, liters of cooking oil and other business needs.

loans.name: Momela Group

texts.en:
Sara is in her mid 30s and is married with three children; two of them are still at school and the third child is young.  

She has run both a general store and mamalishe (food vendor) business for four years.  She works from 8:00am to 9:00pm daily and makes a very good monthly profit.

This will be Sara's 14th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used previous loans to increase her stock of food and sell cold drinks in her general store.  She has successfully repaid her loans.  She used the profit to buy beer, soda, and other stock items. She used the profit to pay school fees, buy land, build a small house and cover household expenses.

She will use this loan to buy beer, soda, and other stock items.  She dreams of finishing her house and selling cold drinks at wholesale prices.

Sara will share this loan with her 3-member loan group "MOMELA" and hold each other accountable for repaying the loan.

loans.use: to buy beer, soda, and stock other items.

loans.name: Nadia Group

texts.en:
Alice, who is in her late 50s, is married, with three children, one of whom is still in college and the other two are grown-up. She has been having several projects, running a business of selling art crafts and selling traditional chicken and small fish since 2005. She works from 9am to 4pm daily and she is able to make a very good monthly profit.

This will be Alice's 13th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy art crafts, started selling traditional chicken, and started selling small fish, which she buys from up-country. She has successfully paid back all her loans. She is doing great and she is grateful for everyone who contributed to supporting her group. She used the profit to pay school fees, built a chicken shade, and covered household expenses. 

Alice will use this loan to buy a good stock of small fish from up-country to meet her customers' demands.  She dreams of opening a retail shop.

Alice will share this loan with her loan group, Nadia Group, with five members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy a good stock of small fish from up-country to meet her customers' demands.

loans.name: Busara 1B Group

texts.en:
Pendo, who is in her mid-20s, is single. She has been running a business, selling soup with chapati, for one year. She works from 6:00am to 12:00 noon daily, and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This is her third loan request from Kiva's partner, Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous two loans to buy business chairs, tables, and food-making ingredients, like baking flour and meat. By doing so, she became able to receive more customers than before. She will use her share of this new loan to buy meat for making soup, baking flour for making chapati, and charcoal for cooking. She dreams that her business will grow, up to the hotel level. Pendo does not posses a higher-level education, but she is able to manage well her business, despite big challenges. She believes that, through Tujijenge loan services, she will be able to grow and meet her business targets. Pendo uses her business profit to meet her life expenses.

She will share this loan with her loan group, "Busara 1B." The group is comprised of six members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy meat for making soup, baking flour for making chapati, and charcoal for cooking.

loans.name: Mkombozi Group

texts.en:
Veronica, who is in her early twenties, is single and has one baby boy, who is in school. For three years, Veronica has been managing a business selling fresh-water fish, specifically, 'dagaa.' Lake 'dagaa' is known for being the best, or more delicious, compared to the oceanic one. She found a market among other towns, where she travels just for selling. She normally spends a few days away from her business center, in other towns where she has a market. If she is in her center she works at her business from 8:00am to 5:00pm, and is able to make a good profit.

This will be Veronica's fourth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans (which she paid back successfully) to buy stocks of dagaa. Veronica managed to earn a profit and used it to cover building expenses, household expenses and school fees. She will use this loan to buy fish to resell, once again. Veronica dreams of expanding her business to big towns, like Arusha and Dar es Salaam, where there is high demand.

She will share this loan with her loan group, "Mkombozi," which has two members. Mkombozi group members will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy fish to resell.

loans.name: Sky Group

texts.en:
Asha, who is in her early thirties, is married and has four children, two sons and two girls.  Asha's kids are in school.  For ten years now, Asha has been managing a dagaa business.  Dagga is a kind of small dry fish from lake water. She wakes up in the early morning (5:00 am) to start her business.  Her business ends at 3:00 pm.  She is able to make a small monthly profit.

This is her second loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan, which was paid back in full, to buy sacks of dagaa. With the business profit, she bought a plot of land where she built a visitor's house. Asha covered school fees and food for her family. She will use this loan to buy dagaa for selling.  In the coming days, Asha would like to open a wholesale shop. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "Sky Group" which consist of five members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy dagaa ( kind of small dry fishes from lake water) for  reselling.

loans.name: Tusisumbuane Group

texts.en:
Ally, who is in his mid-forties, is a married man and has three sons and a daughter. Ally's children are in  school. Ally makes his living by running a motorbike transport business, commonly known as a bodaboda.  It is an industry that now days employs more people in Africa. He has been in this business for four years now.  Ally works at his job from 7 am to 6 pm, but sometimes to midnight hours. He is able to make a small monthly profit.

Ally is requesting a new loan from Kiva partner, Tujijenge Tanzania. This totals Ally's request to five loans that he has borrowed from Tujijenge. He will use this loan to buy a new motorbike for his business. With the previous four loans, which he paid back in full, Ally bought his current motorbike and covered its maintenance expenses. With the profit he made from his business, he used it to build a family house where he is living now. He also covered school fees. He dreams to own a retail shop to diversify his business risk and maximize his income.

Ally will share this loan with his loan group "Tusisumbuane", which totals two members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike for his business.

loans.name: Maendeleo Group

texts.en:
Sudi, who is in his early 40s, is single with two sons who are still at school. He has been running two projects, a transport business (motor cycle) and a retail shop, for six years now. He works from 6am to 10pm daily and is able to make a very good monthly profit.

This will be Sudi's 4th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loans to open the retail shop and to buy spares for his motorcycle. He has paid back all his loans successfully, and has been really happy to have them. He has used the profit to pay school fees, build his house and pay household expenses. He will use this loan to service his motorcycle, and to buy another motorcycle. He dreams of becoming an international business man.

Sudi will share this loan with his loan group "Maendeleo" which has ten members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to service his motorcycle, and to buy another motorcycle.

loans.name: Muheza Group

texts.en:
Senoritha is in her late thirties and is married. She has two daughters who are in school. Senoritha makes her living by managing two related activities. She runs a catering business for different parties, like weddings, funerals or other functions. She is also involved with decorations. Senoritha's activities have no permanent time because it depends on which functions she is going to service. Her business is high at the end of of the year season, so for the other period she can stay even a month without a job. She is working hard and is able to generate a very good profit.

This is Senoritha's thirteen loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans, which she paid back successfully, to buy new decorating materials with nice colors.  She is doing great and her business now shows a good progress.  With her business profit, she used it to buy a home water storage tank and covered household and school expenses. In the coming days, Senoritha would like to be a successful business person. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "Muheza", which consist of three members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy materials for her decoration business.

loans.name: Mshikamano Group

texts.en:
Zaina, who is in her early 20s, is divorced. She has been running a beauty salon for two years, now. She works from 8:00am to 8:00pm daily, and she is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Zaina's fourth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy items that were missing from her salon's stock. She has paid back all her loans successfully. She is doing great! She used the profit for household expenses. She will use her share of this new loan to buy another dryer and other salon equipment. She dreams of becoming an international business woman.

Zaina will share this loan with her loan group, "Mshikamano." The group has nine members, who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy another dryer and other salon equipment.

loans.name: Zingatia Group

texts.en:
Sakina, who is in her mid-40s, is married and has a boy and girl who are in school. For a period of four years now, she has been managing her family by running a shop selling soft drinks like water, sodas and juices. She also sells cooking oil in the same shop. Sakina runs her business from 8 am to 9 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit. 

This will be her third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania and she will use the loan to buy new shop stocks to resell. With her previous loans, all of which she repaid successfully, she bought sold-out business stocks. She reinvested the business profits she earned in her business. Sakina dreams of expanding her business. 

She will share this loan with her loan group Zingatia, which consist of three members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy new stock to resell.

loans.name: Wazo Tegeta Group

texts.en:
Filbert, who is in his mid-forties, is married and has a son and a daughter. One of his kids is in school while the other is still young. Filbert is a businessman who devotes his time to different businesses. He runs a pharmacy, a food shop and a stored-card money-transfer business (M-pesa, Tigo pesa and Airtel). He employs a few helpers who run all sales. Last year, Filbert was in school studying for a certificate and has now graduated. He has been in these businesses for ten years now. Filbert's businesses are open from 7am to 10pm, and he is able to make a very good profit.

This is Filbert's ninth loan request from Tujijenge Tanzania. He will use the loan to increase in his M-pesa, Tigo Pesa and Airtel money vaults to serve more people. He used his previous loans, which he paid back successfully, to open two of his current businesses: money transfers and pharmacy. Filbert earned a profit, which he used to pay school fees for his child and his own tuition fees. Filbert also covered household expenses and saved. His dream is to build a nice family house.

Filbert will share this loan with his loan group, Wazo Tegeta, which totals three members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to increase in his M-pesa, Tigo Pesa and Airtel (money transfer) vaults to serve more people.
